Pallid bats are primarily insectivorous, feeding on a variety of insects, including beetles, scorpions, and crickets. They use a unique hunting strategy, where they drop down from their roosts and capture prey on the ground.

These bats are known for their tolerance to venom, which allows them to feed on scorpions and other venomous arthropods. They are also capable of echolocation, using high-frequency calls to navigate and locate their prey.

Pallid bats roost in a variety of habitats, including caves, abandoned buildings, and rock crevices. They are found in arid and semi-arid regions of western North America, ranging from British Columbia in Canada to central Mexico.

The pallid bat is an important part of the ecosystem, playing a role in controlling insect populations and serving as a food source for predators. It is considered a species of least concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
